Since valence electrons are further from the nucleus, the energy it takes to remove one from an atom is less
Coulomb’s law explains why certain electrons have higher ionization energy
Can convert moles to AMU and back
Inverse square law in Coulomb’s law makes it so distance is a larger determining factor than charge, thus why valence electrons have such a low ionization energy
The more protons an atom has, the heavier it is (See Isotopes and Coulomb’s Law - Moles as to why the more protons an atom has, the heavier a mole of it is)
Atomic radius and electronegativity both play into ionization energy
coulomb's law can be used to describe why ionization energy and atomic radius are inversly related in periodic trends
Chemical bonds are a type of intramolecular force. Strength of bonds determines potential energy of the system.
Ionic solids are made of ionic bonds. Stronger bonds -> stronger solid.
The structure of ionic solids make it so that the system has the lowest possible potential energy.
Delocalized electrons in resonance structures create more stable bonding arrangements with lower potential energy by spreading out electron density and reducing repulsion.
In metals and alloys, delocalized electrons reduce electrostatic repulsion between metal nuclei, minimizing potential energy while still allowing flexibility and conductivity.
Ideal geometries minimize potential energy of the system.
Resonance can slightly shift electron density across a molecule, modifying bond character and influencing idealized geometries and the degree of orbital mixing.
Metals are made out of metallic bonds.
